results.title: Tuktu and his animal friends
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Stories of Tuktu”.
In this film we look at the smaller animals that live in the Arctic, including lemmings, weasels, ducks and kittiwakes. It also includes material on flowers. Tuktu’s father climbs the high cliffs in search of gulls’ eggs.

results.title: Tuktu and the magic spear
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Stories of Tuktu”.
Tuktu accompanies his family when fishing is done through the ice during the long cold winter. He also sees his father catch fish with a spear during the summer, Tuktu longs to grow up and spear fish too.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Tuktu and the magic bow
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Stories of Tuktu”.
The Inuit in far-off times used the bow and arrow for hunting. We see a bow being made and how the Inuit practise their shooting skill by aiming arrows at snow men and snow bears. Tuktu’s father proves himself the best at this test of hunting skill.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Tuktu and the ten thousand fishes
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Stories of Tuktu”.
Tuktu is taken on a fishing trip to the ancient stone weir. He sees his father and other hunters spear fish in great numbers, and watches his father and his uncle make fire with an Inuit fire drill.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: You are growing day by day
results.creator_credit: Hugh Johnston, Suzanne Johnston and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Tackles the concept of growth in children, plants and animals. Also introduces the notion of rates of growth.

results.title: Tuktu and the big seal
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Stories of Tuktu”.
A big seal gets away after being harpooned by Tuktu’s father. Perhaps it is the same seal that has, in the past, escaped the harpoons of other hunters. But Tuktu’s father does bring home a seal in the end.

results.title: Tuktu and his nice new clothes
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Stories of Tuktu”.
Tuktu and other children are shown being fitted for and dressed in warm winter clothes, beautifully made by the Inuit women. We see the cutting, stitching and use of Arctic clothing, and we learn how important it is for Inuit mothers to be clever seamstresses.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: You've Probably Saved His Life
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Film Australia and Tristram Miall
results.brief_description: A dramatised documentary starring Judy Morris and Ivor Kants which is designed to motivate the general public to learn life saving skills such as cardio-vascular resuscitation. A beloved father and husband dies of an acute heart attack. His life could have been saved had his friends and neighbours known how to resuscitate him. An extremely moving film which should be viewed at home, by community and welfare groups, hospitals and schools. This film saves lives.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl McPhee, Film Australia and Tristram Miall

results.title: The Texas chain saw massacre (D)
results.brief_description: Loosely based on the grizzly exploits of American serial killer Ed Gein (also a model for Norman Bates in “Psycho”), Tobe Hooper’s “The Texas chain saw massacre” rightly deserves its place as a horror classic. Five teenagers travelling through Texas (two of them brother and sister investigating the mysterious desecration of their grandfather’s grave), pick up a creepy hitchhiker and find themselves embroiled in a macabre and nightmarish reverse of southern hospitality. From its eerie opening images to its shocking finale, “The Texas chain saw massacre’ was initially considered a cheap drive-in exploitation film but, through strong critical appraisal, went on to be screened as part of the director’s fortnight at Cannes and the American Museum of Modern Art now has a print of it in its permanent collection. Cast includes Marilyn Burns, Allen Danziger and Gunnar Hansen as Leatherface.

results.title: The Test
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Does a little cheating matter? The focus of this film is a conflict that arises in a community when an idealistic teacher chooses to resign her position rather than condone cheating in the classroom. The film, intended for an adult audience, portrays the role of the Home and School Association in providing a middle ground where parents and teachers can meet.
